awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Superconducting Neural Units with Adjustable Weights
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a new neuromorphic computing platform, the effects of which may be seen in many different fields, ranging from the automobile industry to robotics and biomedical applications. The reduction in energy use afforded by the technology could save up to 2% of the total electricity consumption nationwide, making it one of the most environmentally friendly computing platforms. Furthermore, the superconductor-based hardware has the potential to provide one of the fastest commercialized high-performance computing platforms for both industry and research, offering the potential to solve current computational problems in many fields. The development of high-frequency neuromorphic computing, with specific application to artificial intelligence applications, promises to strengthen the US economy. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to bring to the technological forefront a high-speed superconductor electronics-based neuromorphic computer centered around neural units with adjustable weights serving as a disordered array. Currently, high-speed computing necessary for large artificial intelligence models is bottlenecked at semiconductor device architecture as Moore’s Law reaches its limits. Much of the necessary computing power is only accessible via paid run time on vast server banks owned by a select few companies that can afford to build them. By unlocking computing power based on SQUID (superconducting quantum interference device) arrays and rapid single flux quantum (RSFQ), the project aims to develop an affordable, reliable, and carbon friendly high-speed computing platform, thereby helping to solve the power/cost crisis facing currently accessible computing systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing high-scalable, high-frequency, and low-power consumption neural units that mimic behaviors observed in biological brain neurons for neuromorphic computing using superconductor electronics (SCE). The primary goal of this project was to establish the proof-of-concept of neural units using RSFQ and disordered networks to demonstrate the experimental and simulation capabilities in developing a large neuromorphic computing network for machine learning applications.

Intellectual Merit

With the rapid increase in the size of machine learning models and large data, current computational resources and hardware are facing challenges due to their energy and scalability limitations. This project uses superconductor materials with low energy density to overcome the challenge current computational electronics are facing. The project demonstrated properties such as associative memory, long and short-term memory, and classification in simulations and experiments on small fabricated neural units. These fundamental computational properties are widely believed to be the basis for neural network processing in biological brains as well as in machine learning. Such behaviors with parallel structures provides a much more efficient solution for machine learning to save energy and computing power. The neural units also demonstrated incredible characteristics in operating frequency, energy efficiency, and memory density. Experimental data indicates operational spike frequencies reaching up to a few terahertz (THz). By benchmarking the energy consumption of a network, the test yielded an energy consumption that is at least three orders of magnitude less than silicon-based hardware, including memristor networks of identical topology, with the lowest energy consumption. The unit devices can provide over a million memory states, which will increase exponentially with the size of the network, providing a potential solution for high-density data storage.

Broader Impacts

This project developed solutions for superconductor-based neural units, providing the basic structures of neuromorphic computing hardware. The broader impact of this project extends beyond neuromorphic computing itself. The envisioned technology has applications spanning various fields, including the automobile industry, robotics, and biomedical applications. The potential implementation and application in data analysis, decision making, and cybert securty will be crucial for the future of national defenseThe reduction in energy consumption positions the future product as one of the most environmentally friendly computing solutions. It can significantly reduce the power consumption of current servers and data centers, which is over 2% of the total nationwide electricity consumption.

 

The project has provided the PI, one post-doctoral scholar, and serval undergraduate students with professional development opportunities. It has also led to several collaborations centered on the neural units developed.

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2024
Modified by: Yuchao Zhou
